data.source: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) for COVID-19 cases and population; meteoblue.com for climate (yearly average temperature and precipitation); World Bank for economic openness; Democracy index scores (2019).
data.wave_or_subset: Cross-country data covering 163 countries with available data, as of April 5, 2020.
data.notes: Data compiled from multiple public sources; incomplete data led to exclusion of some countries. Outcome measured as confirmed cases per million population. Measurement date noted as April 5, 2020.

method.description: The study uses cross-country regression (classical linear regression with OLS) to examine associations between confirmed COVID-19 cases per million and environmental (temperature, precipitation), economic (openness), and social/political (democracy index) factors. Population density was initially included. Autoregressive dynamics were considered via lagged cases; to mitigate multicollinearity with the lagged variable, residualization was applied and the residuals were included in the final estimable model. Diagnostic tests assessed heteroscedasticity, normality, and autocorrelation.
steps: Collect COVID-19 confirmed case counts and population data from ECDC; compute cases per million by country.
Collect yearly average temperature and precipitation data from meteoblue.com.
Collect economic openness (trade-to-GDP ratio) from the World Bank.
Specify baseline regression with temperature, precipitation, economic openness, democracy index, and population density as predictors.
Consider autoregressive structure by including lagged infection cases; address multicollinearity by regressing the lagged variable on other predictors and using residuals in the final model.
Estimate models using OLS; evaluate lags (1–9), and exclude non-significant variables (precipitation, population density) from subsequent specifications.
Conduct diagnostic checks (R^2, SER, tests for heteroscedasticity, normality, and autocorrelation).
method.models: Classical Linear Regression (OLS); models with and without lagged dependent variable; residualization approach to include lagged effects while handling multicollinearity. Representative final form: Y_i = α + β1*Temperature + β2*Precipitation + β3*Openness + β4*Democracy + β5*PopulationDensity + θ*v_hat + u_i, where v_hat are residuals from regressing lagged cases on other predictors.
method.outcome_variable: Number of confirmed COVID-19 cases per million people (country-level)
method.independent_variables: Yearly average temperature; yearly average precipitation; economic openness (trade-to-GDP); democracy index (2019); population density; lagged infection cases (via residuals).
method.control_variables: Yearly average precipitation; population density; residualized lag of infection cases.

results.summary: Higher average temperature is associated with fewer COVID-19 cases per million, while greater economic openness and higher democracy index scores are associated with more cases per million. Precipitation and population density were not significant and were dropped. Coefficients for temperature, openness, and democracy were stable across different lag specifications. Diagnostics indicated heteroscedasticity and non-normal residuals, with little autocorrelation (except in one model).

metadata.original_paper_title: Is the spread of COVID-19 across countries influenced by environmental, economic and social factors?
